responses: Hello! How are you feeling today?
Hi there! How can I support you?
Welcome to Dr. AI. How have you been feeling lately?
Good to see you. What's on your mind today?
Welcome back. How can I assist you today?
I'm sorry you're feeling this way. Let's explore some strategies that might help.
It sounds tough right now. I'd like to understand more about what you're experiencing.
Thank you for sharing that with me. Many people experience similar feelings.
That sounds challenging. Let's break this down together.
I appreciate you sharing this. Let's explore ways to help you cope.
follow_ups: How long have you been feeling this way?
On a scale of 1-10, how intense is this feeling?
Have you noticed any specific triggers for these feelings?
Has anything helped you feel even slightly better?
How is this affecting your daily life?

responses: Please contact the Suicide Hotline at 988 immediately. You are not alone and help is available.
I'm concerned about what you're sharing. Please call the Crisis Helpline at 988 right away. They can provide immediate support.
Your safety is my top priority. Please reach out to 988 for immediate help from trained professionals.

patterns: How can I move my body to feel better
responses: Physical movement can really help with mental health. Even a short walk or gentle stretching can make a difference.
Movement is great for releasing tension. Simple stretches or brief walks can help shift your mood.
Our bodies and minds are connected. Even 5 minutes of gentle movement can help change how you feel.
recommendations: Try Child's Pose: kneel on the floor, sit back on your heels, extend arms forward, and rest your forehead on the ground. Breathe deeply for 1-2 minutes.
A 10-minute walk outside, focusing on what you see, hear, and feel, can help break thought cycles.
Try progressive muscle relaxation: tense each muscle group for 5 seconds, then release, moving from feet to head.
Dance to your favorite song for 3 minutes - let your body move freely without judgment.
Try 'Sun Breath' standing stretch: Reach arms overhead while inhaling, fold forward while exhaling.

responses: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) helps identify and change unhelpful thought patterns. It's quite effective for many mental health concerns.
Our thoughts strongly influence our feelings and behaviors. Working with these connections can be very helpful.
Recognizing thought patterns is the first step toward changing them. Let me share a simple technique.
techniques: Try the 'STOP' technique: Stop, Take a breath, Observe your thoughts without judgment, Proceed with more awareness.
Practice thought challenging: When you notice a negative thought, ask 'What's the evidence for and against this thought?' and 'Is there another way to look at this situation?'
For worry thoughts, try scheduled worry time: Set aside 15 minutes daily to write out all your worries, then try to postpone worry thoughts until that time.
Create coping statements: Develop positive affirmations like 'This feeling will pass' or 'I can handle this'.
Use behavioral activation: Schedule one small positive activity each day, even if you don't feel motivated.

responses: Speaking with a professional can be incredibly helpful. There are several ways to connect with qualified therapists.
A mental health professional can provide personalized support. Here are some resources to help you find one.
It takes courage to seek professional help, and it's often very beneficial. Here are some options to consider.
resources: The SAMHSA National Helpline (1-800-662-4357) can connect you with local resources.
Psychology Today has a therapist directory at psychologytoday.com where you can search by location and specialty.
Many areas have community mental health centers that offer services on a sliding fee scale based on income.
BetterHelp (betterhelp.com) offers online therapy with licensed professionals.
The Crisis Text Line provides free 24/7 support by texting HOME to 741741.

responses: Self-care is an important part of mental wellness. Even small actions can make a difference.
Taking care of yourself doesn't have to be complicated. Simple daily practices can help support your mental health.
Building self-care into your routine can help create stability and resilience.
practices: Try the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding exercise: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste.
Practice a brief daily gratitude ritual - write down 3 specific things you appreciate each day.
Set a timer for just 2 minutes of focused deep breathing - inhale for 4 counts, hold for 2, exhale for 6.
Create a 'comfort box' with items that engage your senses (soft fabric, calming scents, soothing music).
Try bilateral stimulation: Alternate tapping left and right sides of your body to help calm the nervous system.

responses: Sleep difficulties can significantly impact how we feel. There are several evidence-based approaches that might help.
Sleep and mental health are closely connected. Improving sleep often helps with many emotional challenges.
Sleep problems are very common, especially during stressful periods. Let me share some approaches that have helped others.
practices: Try to keep a consistent sleep schedule, going to bed and waking up at the same time each day, even on weekends.
Develop a wind-down routine: dim the lights, avoid screens for 30-60 minutes before bed, and try reading or gentle stretching.
If you can't fall asleep after 20 minutes, get up and do something relaxing in dim light until you feel sleepy again.
Practice the 4-7-8 breathing technique: Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 7, exhale for 8.
Try progressive muscle relaxation starting from your toes and working up to your head.

responses: I'm connecting you to our partner network of licensed professionals. Please choose an option:
Let me help you find professional support. What type of consultation would you prefer?
